data.stimulus:
We will start today's lesson with a review of Academic Writing...

 

 

 

Here are some characteristics of Academic Writing.

► Complete the points below by choosing the correct heading from the drop down.

Note: there is one extra option that you don't need.
data.template:
Academic writing... 

... answers a question and demonstrates an understanding of the subject.
► This means that academic writing should be {{response}}.

... is coherent, written in a logical order, and brings together related points and material. 
► This means that academic writing should be {{response}}.

... supports all opinions and arguments with evidence. 
► This means that academic writing should be {{response}}.

... uses appropriate language and tenses, and is clear, concise and balanced. 
► This means that academic writing should be {{response}}.

... should make a logical and objective argument. Whether you personally agree or disagree with an idea, it must be presented accurately and objectively in your paper. 
► This means that academic writing should be {{response}}.

data.stimulus:
Here are some things you should avoid when writing academic texts. 

► Complete the points below by choosing the correct option from the drop down.

 

Note: there is one option that you don't need.
data.template:
Things to avoid: 

The goal of academic writing is to express complex ideas in a clear, concise manner. Avoid confusing language and long sentences (as a general rule, no more than 40 words per sentence).
► This means that academic writing should NOT be {{response}}.

Academic writing is formal in tone and should not include slang, idioms, or conversational language.
► This means that academic writing should NOT be {{response}}.

Academic writing must go beyond the writer’s own ideas. Make sure do your research to find evidence to back your claims.
► This means that academic writing should NOT be {{response}}.

Do not just repeat the ideas or arguments from your source materials. Rather, analyse those arguments and explain how they relate to your point.
► This means that academic writing should NOT be {{response}}.

stems: Long sentences with more than 40 words
Linking words and phrases such as and, but, so
Linking words and phrases such as in addition, although, therefore
data.stimulus:
Academic writing should be formal.

► Let's recap some characteristics of  formal writing.

ui_style.stem_title: In formal / academic writing style, we use...

data.stimulus:
In the paragraph below, the writer used several expressions which are not suitable for an academic report. They are underlined in red below.

 

 

Mach each unsuitable expression with the reason why there're not appropriate for academic writing.

(NOTE: You can use some reasons more than once)

 

How to make people work harder is a topic that lots of people have written about for a long time. There are lots of different theories and I think some of them are ok. When we think about this we should remember the old proverb, that you can lead a horse to water but you can’t make it drink. So what is the effect of motivation on staff? It’s quite a complex subject but I will just talk about a couple of ideas, like productivity.
data.template:
Unsuitable Expressions ⇒ Reasons

  • How to make people work harder ⇒ {{response}}
  • lots of (people / theories) ⇒ {{response}}
  • for a long time ⇒ {{response}}
  • I think / we think / we should / I will ⇒ {{response}}
  • OK ⇒ {{response}}
  • Old proverb ⇒ {{response}}
  • So, what is the effect of motivation? ⇒ {{response}}
  • It's / can't ⇒ {{response}}
  • A couple ⇒ {{response}}
  • like ⇒ {{response}}

data.stimulus: Now lets replace the unsuitable words with some more appropriate options.
data.template:
{{response}} has been the topic of {{response}} written during {{response}}. There are {{response}} different theories on the subject, but {{response}} Maslow’s hierarchy of needs theory (1943) and Herzberg’s two-factor theory (1966).  

Given that motivation may affect the {{response}} in numerous ways, this study will {{response}} to the importance of motivation for high levels of productivity.

value: A significant / considerable number of
Do not / cannot / is not

possible_responses: A significant / considerable number of
Do not / cannot / is not
data.stimulus:
Here are some more examples of language to avoid in academic writing.

Match the with suitable alternatives.

value: A significant / considerable number of
Do not / cannot / is not

data.stimulus:
During the PSE course, we have learned about Topic Sentences.

► Let's start by checking what you can remember...

 

Choose the correct answers in the quiz below.

 

1. The topic sentence usually comes at...

options.label: say what the paragraph is about.

data.stimulus: 2. The purpose of the topic sentence is to...
3. A topic sentence should include evidence or examples.

value: focus only on the topic of marketing.

possible_responses: focus only on the topic of marketing.
focus on marketing and also sales.
include information about the company background.
data.template:
A topic sentences helps you keep the focus of each part of the text.
► For example, if the topic sentence is about marketing strategies, then the rest of that paragraph should {{response}}.

value: focus only on the topic of marketing.

data.stimulus:
Next, let's have look at how to write a topic sentence.

 

There are several ways to form topic sentences.

► In this activity you will analyse different sentence structures which are useful for writing topic sentences.

 

 

⇒ 1. You can start a topic sentence with an -ING form: 

(organise the words into complete sentences)

⇒ 2. You can start a topic sentence with "There are": 

(organise the words into complete sentences)

⇒ 3. You can start a topic sentence with a "It is + adjective":

(organise the words into complete sentences)

Here is a similar paragraph, with the same structure and a different topic.

 

► Select the correct linkers from the drop down.
data.template: There are several reasons why our company should move to remote working. {{response}}, we will spend less money on rent as we will a much smaller office. {{response}}, staff will also be able to save money because they will not have to commute. {{response}} they will have more disposable income and feel more motivated. {{response}}, there is evidence that staff working from home are more productive. A report from Harvard Business Review (2014) argues that {{response}} having less controls, people tend to work harder if they feel more satisfied with their job.

data.stimulus:
As we have seen in the exercises above, linking words are essential to structure your paragraphs.

► Below you can see a variety of linking words, with different uses and functions.

► Add them to the table.
